title: Geraldine woman fumes over tourists toileting in her garden
text:
Geraldine woman fumes over tourists toileting in her garden ESTHER ASHBY-COVENTRY Last updated 18:27, February 1 2017 TETSURO MITOMO/FAIRFAX NZ 
Geraldine home owner Jenny Wynn wonders how anyone could mistake her property for a public place to go to the toilet -.three tourists did. 
A Geraldine home owner is mortified after three people believed to be tourists left faeces-covered toilet paper in her wheelie bin and wandered around her property when she was away. 
"The public toilets are on the same street," Jenny Wynn said. 
The Cox St public toilets are about 900 metres east of Wynn's home. 
She was in Tekapo on Saturday when the tourists allegedly stopped their car, dropped rubbish into her wheelie bin, then walked up her tree-lined driveway and meandered around her back garden for "some time". 
Her neighbour, who did not want her name published, spotted the three strangers as they tipped their rubbish into Wynn's bin and wandered up her driveway. 
"They were round the back (of the house) for ages so I went up there and asked them what they thought they were doing," the neighbour said. 
Their answer was one word, "toilet". 
"I told them 'no you don't' and told them where the public toilets were. It's disgusting," she said. 
When Wynn returned home she was shocked to discover the travellers had left not just their rubbish in her wheelie bin, but toilet paper covered in faecal matter. 
"It felt like a home invasion. I used rubber gloves and burnt the toilet paper." 
She was unsure exactly what they had left in her garden but was reluctant to do any gardening in case she made an unwelcome discovery. 
"They have invaded my privacy. I want people to know this is not ok," she said. 
Fortunately her neighbour managed to write down the perpetrators' car registration number and will pass it on to police. 
Geraldine ward councillor Kerry Stevens said it was totally unacceptable and unhygienic behaviour. He was not aware of such an incident occurring before and he hoped it never happened again. 
"I feel sorry for the woman (Wynn)." 
There was no lack of public toilets in Geraldine, with the town voted one of the top 10 places for a "pit stop" in New Zealand, according to a recent AA Traveller survey, Stevens said. 
A new $181,000 public toilet block next to the existing women's public toilets on Cox St is expected to be up and running by April. 
Geraldine Community Board member Janene​ Adams said she was one of a few committee members in the process of designing the photofilm exterior for the new toilet block. 
"We thought we may have a local forest scene with information boxes scattered throughout. We are lucky to have Peel and Talbot forests so close by."
